subdivision_of_building: School Phase and Part of Phase 3
site_name: Part Of The Green Man Lane Estate (Including Part Of Tintern Court And The Green Man Lane Estate Community Centre) Jubilee Hall And St Johns First

superseding_details.component_description: D1 Jubilee Centre, Dean Hall, Community Centre

open_spaces_details.open_space_type: Provision for children and young people

protected_spaces_details.description: Provision for children and young people

description: Demolition of all buildings and structures within the site (including Jubilee Hall, Green Man Lane Estate Community Centre, St John's First and Middle School, and 88-134 Tintern Court (North) and blocks comprising 18-21, 22-24, 42-45 and 51-53 Tintern Court, part of 15-17 Tintern Court, part of 36-41 Tintern Court, and part of 46 & 47 Tintern Court) and the phased construction of 92 residential units (26 x one-bedroom, 40 x two-bedroom, 3 x three-bedroom flats, and 20 x three-bedroom houses and 3 x four-bedroom houses in a mix of housing tenures) in apartment buildings varying between three-storeys and six-storeys high and including a row of 23 two-storey terraced houses (with accommodation in the roof) and associated refuse / recycling and bicycle storage facilities; community floorspace at ground floor level of the apartment buildings comprising 766sq.m floorspace (flexible D1 / D2 Use Class); a nursery and three-form entry primary school accommodated in buildings varying between two-storeys and three-storeys high with 3,937sq.m floorspace (D1 Use Class), together with associated playspace and a multi-use games area; alterations to the adopted highways (including Felix Road, Romsey Road and Green Man Lane) incorporating the setting-out of 70 car parking spaces and re-provided footways; site-wide hard and soft landscaping; and other associated infrastructure works.
decision_conditions: The development permitted shall be begun before the expiration of three years from the date of this permission.  Reason: In order to comply with the provisions of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (as amended). | The development hereby permitted shall be carried out in accordance with the following approved plans: (2464 PL-) 001 PL; 002 PL; 003 PL; 004 PL; 010 PL; 011 PL; 012 PL; 050 PL; 100 PL-A; 101 PL; 200 PL-A; 201 PL; 202 PL; 203 PL; 204 PL; 205 PL; 206 PL; 207 PL; 208 PL; 209 PL; 210 PL; 300 PL-A; 301 PL; 302 PL; 303 PL; 304 PL; 305 PL; 306 PL-A; 400 PL; 401 PL; 402 PL; 403 PL; 404 PL; 405 PL; 406 PL; 501 PL-A; 502 PL; 503 PL; 504 PL; 505 PL; 506 PL; 507 PL; 509 PL; 510 PL-A; 511 PL; 512 PL; 513 PL; 514 PL; 515 PL; 516 PL; 517 PL; 601 PL-A; 602 PL; 701 PL; 801 PL; 802 PL; 803 PL; 804 PL; (30685) L-90-P-002 P2, L-90-P-003 P2; Technical reports: Air Quality Assessment ref: 47046590 (dated December 2014), prepared by URS; Arboricultural Report and Tree Survey (8519/01 Rev A) ref: AP/8519-RevA/WDC, prepared by Ian Keen Ltd; Construction Management Plan (dated 05/01/2015), prepared by Rydon Construction Ltd; Daylight and Sunlight Report, prepared by EB7; Delivery and Servicing Management Plan ref: 100001747_DSP Rev 02 (dated 19/12/2014), prepared by Project Centre; Design and Access Statement ref: DO-001 Rev-PL (dated January 2015), prepared by Conran and Partners; Energy Strategy ref: 47046590 (dated December 2014), prepared by URS; External Lighting Report ref: 47046590 (dated December 2014), prepared by URS; Flood Risk Assessment version 1.2 (dated 22/12/2014), prepared by Ridge and Partners LLP; Framework Travel Plan ref: 1000001747_FTP 04 (dated 25/02/2015), prepared by Project Centre; Health Impact Assessment, prepared by Savills; Land Contamination Desk Study Report ref: C13484, prepared by Ground Engineering Ltd; Noise and Vibration Assessment Rev D, ref: 141447 (dated 19/12/2014), prepared by Sharps Redmore Acoustic Consultants; Preliminary Ecological Assessment ref: RT-MME-117402, prepared by Middlemarch Environmental; Site Waste Management Plan, prepared by Rydon Construction Ltd (including the additional information received by email prepared by Ms S. Patel, dated 05/03/2015); Sustainability Statement ref: 47046590 (dated December 2014), prepared by URS; Outline Surface Water Drainage Strategy, prepared by Ridge and Partners Ltd; Post-submission response to Transport comments ref: 1000001747/150216 /CH/ Green Man Lane School Phase (dated 16/02/2015, 27/02/2015 and 13/03/2015) and drawing ref: 1000001747-2-611-08, prepared by Project Centre; Response to GLA Stage 1 Report (dated 16/03/2015), prepared by Savills; Response to GLA Final (Climate change and energy) ref: 47046590 (dated 16/03/2015), prepared by URS; Response to LB Ealing Energy comments prepared by URS, dated 16/03/2015; Landscape Design Report ref: 30685_1800_001, (dated January 2015), prepared by Broadway Malyan; Architectural Statement (response note to LBE comments), (dated 07/04/2015), prepared by Conran and Partners; 30685-L-90-00-GML Area Calculations; Applicant Response to LBE comments on 31/03/2015 (received 13/04/2015); Marked-up Phasing Plan (extract from DAS) and Green Man Lane Masterplan Programme (dated February 2015); Vehicle Tracking Diagrams 14145-5000 and 14145-5001; Air Quality and Dust Management Plan ref: 47046590 (dated May 2015, received 22/05/2015), prepared by URS.  Reason: For the avoidance of doubt and in the interests of proper planning. | The works to provide the approved school and nursery shall be carried out in accordance with the approved Construction Management Plan (dated 05/01/2015), prepared by Rydon Construction Ltd, Vehicle Tracking Diagrams 14145-5000 and 14145-5001, and Air Quality and Dust Management Plan ref: 47046590 (dated May 2015, received 22/05/2015), prepared by URS.  Development shall not commence on the approved residential and community development until a site construction management and logistics plan for the relevant phase is submitted to the Local Planning Authority for written approval. The submission shall include the following information: a)	A demolition and construction phasing plan for the application site and the same for the remaining areas of demolition and construction in the wider Green Man Lane estate regeneration masterplan; b)	Details of the number of on-site construction workers and of the transport options for them; c)	anticipated route, anticipated number, frequency and size of construction vehicles entering/exiting the site per day; d)	delivery times and booking system; e)	route and location of site access for construction traffic and associated signage based on the construction vehicle access and egress routes; f)	management of consolidated or re-timed trips; g)	an AQDMP that includes an Air Quality (Dust) Risk Assessment and details of noise/vibration mitigation measures and monitoring arrangements for noise, vibration and dust by suitably qualified noise and air quality specialists.  Noise/vibration and dust mitigation measures must accord with the Mayor's SPG 'The control of dust and emissions from construction and demolition ' (2014); BS 5228 Parts 1 & 2; the Institute of Air Quality Management 'Guidance on the assessment of dust from demolition and construction'; h)	details of site security and the erection and maintenance of security hoarding including decorative displays and facilities for public viewing, where appropriate; i)	secure, off-street loading and drop-off facilities; j)	vehicle manoeuvring and turning, including swept path diagrams to demonstrate how construction vehicles will access the site and be able to turn into and emerge from the site in forward gear and including details of any temporary vehicle access points; k)	details of the location for storage of building materials and construction debris and contractors offices; l)	procedures for on-site contractors to deal with complaints from members of the public; m)	measures to consult cyclists, disabled people and the local schools with regard  to delivery times and necessary diversions; n)	details of all pedestrian and cyclist diversions; o)	a commitment to be part of Considerate Constructors Scheme; and p)	confirmation of use of TfL's Freight Operator Recognition Scheme (FORS) or similar.  Prior to the commencement of any site work, all sensitive properties within or surrounding the site shall be notified in writing of the nature and duration of the works to be undertaken, and the name and address of a responsible person to whom enquiries / complaints should be directed. These details shall also be displayed at regular intervals around the site compound. The development shall be carried out strictly in accordance with the details so approved.  Reason:  The details of a site construction management and logistics plan are required before the commencement of the residential development in order to ensure that appropriate mitigation measures are out in place to protect the amenity of local residents that live in close proximity to the demolition and construction site and to ensure adequate highway and site safety, in accordance with policies 5.3, 5.18, 6.3, 7.14, 7.15 and 7.19 of the London Plan 2015; policies 1.1(e), 1.1(f) and 1.1(j) of Ealing's Development (or Core) Strategy 2012; policy 7A of Ealing's Development Management DPD; (Interim) SPG 10: Noise and Vibration; the National Planning Policy Framework (2012); the Greater London Authority SPG 'The Control of Dust and Emissions from Construction and Demolition' (2014), BS 5228-1:2009 - Code of practice for noise & vibration control on construction & open sites-Part 1: Noise. | The development shall be carried out in accordance with the approved Site Waste Management Plan, prepared by Rydon Construction Ltd (including the additional information received by email prepared by Ms S. Patel on behalf of Savills, dated 05/03/2015).  Reason:  To ensure sustainable procurement of materials which minimises the negative environmental impacts of construction in accordance with policies 5.3 and 5.18 of the London Plan 2015 and policies 1.1 (k) and 1.2 (f) of Ealing's Development (or Core) Strategy 2012. | Development shall not commence on each Phase of development (excluding demolition, site clearance and preparation works) until a piling risk assessment and method statement for the relevant Phase has been submitted to the Local Planning Authority for written approval. The piling risk assessment should demonstrate that the chosen method of piling would not increase the risk of near-surface pollutants migrating into deeper geological formations and aquifers. The Piling Method Statement should include details of the type of piling to be undertaken and the methodology by which such piling would be carried out, including measures to prevent and minimise the potential for damage to subsurface water or sewage infrastructure. The development shall thereafter be carried out in accordance with the approved details.  Reason: Details of piling are required before the sub-structure works commence because Thames Water would require that any proposed piling methods do not pose a pollution risk to controlled waters, water or sewage infrastructure in accordance with policy 5.14 of the London Plan 2015 and policy 1.1(j) of Ealing's Development (or Core) Strategy 2012. | Development shall not commence on each Phase of development (excluding demolition, site clearance and preparation works) until a waste water drainage strategy detailing the on-site and off-site waste water drainage works for the relevant Phase has been submitted to the Local Planning Authority for written approval. There shall be no discharge of foul or surface water from the site into the public system until the drainage works approved by the waste water drainage strategy have been completed.   Reason:  Details of the waste water infrastructure are required before the sub-structure works are commenced so that Thames Water could properly consider what additional infrastructure is required to ensure that sufficient waste water capacity is provided in order to cope with the approved development, and so that the applicant could make provision for such infrastructure as part of the construction programme, in accordance with policy 5.14 of the London Plan 2015; and policy 6.1 of Ealing's Development (or Core) Strategy 2012. | Development shall not commence on each Phase of development (excluding demolition, site clearance and preparation works) until a detailed surface water drainage scheme for the entire application site, based on the agreed Flood Risk Assessment version 1.2, dated 22/12/2014 (FRA) and the approved Outline Surface Water Drainage Strategy, prepared by Ridge and Partners Ltd, has been submitted to the Local Planning Authority for written approval. The drainage strategy shall include a restriction of 35.4/s and surface water storage on site as outlined in the approved FRA has been submitted to the Local Planning Authority for written approval. The scheme shall be consistent with the approved FRA, including the provision of 1830m¦ of green roofs. The detailed surface water drainage scheme shall include the following information: a)	A clearly labelled drainage layout plan showing pipe networks and any attenuation areas or storage locations. This plan should show any pipe 'node numbers' that have been referred to in network calculations and it should also show invert and cover levels of manholes.  b)	Confirmation of the critical storm duration.  c)	Where infiltration forms part of the proposed stormwater system such as infiltration trenches and soakaways, soakage test results and test locations are to be submitted in accordance with BRE digest 365.  d)	Where on site attenuation is achieved through ponds, swales, geocellular storage or other similar methods, calculations showing the volume of these are also required.  e)	Where an outfall discharge control device is to be used such as a hydrobrake or twin orifice, this should be shown on the plan with the rate of discharge stated.  f)	Calculations should demonstrate how the system operates during a 1 in 100 chance in any year critical duration storm event, including an allowance for climate change in line with the 'Planning Practice Guidance: Flood Risk and Coastal Change'. If overland flooding occurs in this event, a plan should also be submitted detailing the location of overland flow paths and the extent and depth of ponding.   The approved surface water drainage scheme shall be implemented on a Phased-basis and subsequently maintained in accordance with the approved arrangements.  Reason: Details of the surface water scheme are required before sub-structure works commenced because the Environment Agency require the applicant to make provision within the construction programme and proposed development for adequate drainage to reduce the risk of flooding to the proposed development and locality, and to enhance water quality and biodiversity, in accordance with the objectives of Section 11 of the NPPF; policies 5.3, 5.12, 5.13 and 5.14 of the London Plan 2015; policy 1.2(m) of Ealing's Development (or Core) Strategy, and policy LV5.12 of Ealing's Development Management DPD. | Development shall not commence on each Phase of development until an Arboricultural Method Statement for the protection of the trees, shrubs and hedgerows to be retained as part of the relevant Phase of development, as set out in Arboricultural Report and Tree Survey (8519/01 Rev A) ref: AP/8519-RevA/WDC, prepared by Ian Keen Ltd (specifically trees 15, 17, 18, 19, 20, 25, 27, 29, 34, 45, 46, 47, 48, 49, 50, 51, 52 and 53 shown on Tree Constraints Plan 8519/01 Rev A 1/2 and 8519/01 Rev A 2/2); and a suitable monitoring programme for the tree protection measures have been submitted to the Local Planning Authority for written approval. All works shall thereafter be carried out in accordance with the approved Arboricultural Method Statement. All tree protection measures must fully detail each phase of the development process taking into account the demolition and site clearance works, all construction works and hard and soft landscaping works.  Details shall include the following: a)	Full survey of all trees on site and those within influencing distance on adjacent sites in accordance with BS5837*, with tree works proposals.  All trees must be plotted on a site plan**, clearly and accurately depicting trunk locations, root protection areas and canopy spreads. b)	A plan** detailing all trees, shrubs, hedges planned for retention and removal. c)	Soil assessments/survey d)	Timing and phasing of works e)	Site specific demolition and hard surface removal specifications f)	Site specific construction specifications g)	Access arrangements and car parking h)	Level changes i)	A Tree protection plan** in accordance with BS5837* detailing all methods of protection, including but not restricted to: locations of construction exclusion zones, root protection areas, fit for purpose fencing and ground protection, service routes, works access space, material/machinery/waste storage and permanent & temporary hard surfaces.   j)	Soil remediation plans. k)	Confirmation of who shall be the lead Arboriculturist and the Site Manager for the development, including their contact details; l)	Procedures for dealing with variations or non-approved incursions into the construction exclusion zones as detailed in the approved Arboricultural Method Statement. m)	Agreements of when site monitoring will take place with the local Tree Officer either by site meetings or by some other pre-arranged agreement.  n)	Post development assessment of the retained and planted trees and any necessary remedial action.   All tree protection methods detailed in the approved Arboricultural Method Statement shall not be moved or removed, temporarily or otherwise, until all works associated with that Phase, including external works have been completed and all equipment, machinery and surplus materials have been removed from the site, unless the prior approval of the Local Planning Authority has first been sought and obtained.  The program of Arboricultural monitoring shall be taken in full compliance with the approved details.    *Using the most recent revision the of the Standard ** Plans must be of a minimum scale of 1:200 (unless otherwise agreed by the Local Planning Authority)  Reason: Details of the Arboricultural Method Statement and a programme of monitoring the tree works are required prior to the commencement of any site preparation works because such works would carry a high risk of damaging trees and other vegetation particularly by site operatives that are not experienced to carry out works around trees. The protection of trees and other vegetation is required in accordance with policies 7.19 and 7.21 of the London Plan 2015, and interim SPG 9 'Trees and Development Guidelines'. | Notwithstanding the detailed hard and soft landscaping works, boundary treatments and details of Secured by Design fences and gates illustrated on approved drawings ref: (30685) L-90-P-002 P2, L-90-P-003 P2 and as detailed in the approved Landscape Design Report ref: 30685_1800_001, prepared by Broadway Malyan and Design and Access Statement ref: DO-001 Rev-PL (dated January 2015), prepared by Conran and Partners, further details of the landscaping proposals shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority within three months of the commencement of each Phase in respect of the following matters (and relating to the relevant Phase of development): a) Full details of the design of the children play areas, including safety surfacing and equipment (where relevant); b) Soft landscaping: including grass and turf areas, hedges, shrub and herbaceous areas, allotments and tree strategy including species type and size at planting. Tree species should include a palette of different species of trees in order to avoid streets and long sections of landscaping that are planted in monocultures; c) Hard landscaping: including ground surfaces, kerbs, edges, ridge and flexible paving, seating or other public realm furniture, steps, and any synthetic surfaces and a drawing illustrating the Local Highways Authority adoption boundary; d) Enclosures and boundary treatments, including types, dimensions and finishes of walls, fences, screen walls, barriers, bollards, rails, retaining walls and hedges; e) A statement detailing how the landscaping proposals contribute to the mitigation measures for nesting birds, the enablement of species to migrate such as hedgehogs and other small mammals through gaps in fencing and ecological enhancements, including the number and location of swift boxes, sparrow terrace, bat bricks, bee boxes and other measures to enhance ecology (as relevant);  f) Work phasing plan.  (The submission should exclude the details of the on-street parking spaces, new and replacement footways and carriageways, and landscaping within the part of the site to be adopted by the Local Highways Authority (LHA), and the details of the acoustic fencing to be installed around the perimeter of the multi-use games area).  All soft landscaping shall be carried out in the earliest planting season (1st October to 31st March inclusive). The quality of all approved landscape works shall be in accordance with British Standard 4428:1989 'Code of Practice for General Landscape Operations' or any subsequent revision.  All trees included within the approved scheme shall be healthy, well-formed specimens with single leading shoots and shall be of a minimum quality compatible with British Standard 3936:1992 (Part 1) 'Specifications For Trees & Shrubs' and British Standard 4043 (where applicable) or any subsequent revisions and BS:8545:2014 Trees: from nursery to independence in the landscape.  Any trees that within a period of 5 years from the completion of all tree planting, that die, are removed, uprooted, are significantly damaged, become diseased or malformed shall be replaced during the nearest planting season (1st October to 31st March inclusive) with others of the same size, species and quality as approved. The development shall thereafter be carried out in accordance with the approved plans and work phasing plan. Boundary treatments shall be fully provided before the first occupation of the part of development which it forms part. The approved details shall be retained thereafter.   Reason: To ensure that the development is landscaped in the interests of the positive visual character and appearance of the area; to ensure that the necessary boundary treatments are incorporated into the development in the interests of meeting the Secured by Design principles; in order to ensure that the site landscaping is provided in accordance with an agreed timeframe; and in order to provide a good level of privacy for future users / occupants, in accordance with policies LV2.18, LV7.3, LV7.4, 7B and 7D of Ealing's Development Management DPD (2013); 2.18, 7.4, 7.13, 7.19 and 7.21 of the London Plan 2015; 1.1(h) and (i), 2.10, 5.3, 5.4 and 6.3 of Ealing's Development (or Core) Strategy 2012, and interim SPG 9 'Trees and Development Guidelines'. | Notwithstanding the indicative design and layout of the on-street parking spaces, footways, carriageways and landscaping within the part of the site to be adopted by the Local Highways Authority (LHA) and shown on the approved plans, the final detailed design of these elements of the development and a phasing programme for their construction / implementation shall be submitted to the Local Planning Authority for written approval prior to the commencement of the development (excluding demolition, site clearance and preparation works). The submission shall also include details of the street tree pits, tree species and the size of street trees at the time of planting.  The final detailed design of the on-street parking spaces, footways, carriageways and landscaping shall need to ensure the protection of trees identified for retention in the approved Arboricultural Report and Tree Survey (8519/01 Rev A) ref: AP/8519-RevA/WDC, prepared by Ian Keen Ltd, and to use best endeavours to provide a 4.8m wide running carriageway along the part of Felix Road within the application site. The detailed design of the layout of the on-street parking spaces, footways, carriageways and landscaping should be discussed with the LHA prior to the submission of details to the Local Planning Authority. All soft landscaping shall be carried out in the earliest planting season (1st October to 31st March inclusive). The quality of all approved landscape works shall be in accordance with British Standard 4428:1989 'Code of Practice for General Landscape Operations' or any subsequent revision.  All trees included within the approved scheme shall be healthy, well-formed specimens with single leading shoots and shall be of a minimum quality compatible with British Standard 3936:1992 (Part 1) 'Specifications For Trees & Shrubs' and British Standard 4043 (where applicable) or any subsequent revisions and BS 8545:2014 Trees: from nursery to independence in the landscape.  Any trees that within a period of 5 years from the completion of all tree planting, that die, are removed, uprooted, are significantly damaged, become diseased or malformed shall be replaced during the nearest planting season (1st October to 31st March inclusive) with others of the same size, species and quality as approved. The on-street parking spaces, new and replacement footways and carriageways, and landscaping shall be provided in accordance with the approved details and the approved phasing programme and retained thereafter.  Reason: To safeguard the future of  existing significant trees in the interests of the visual amenities and the biodiversity value of the area and the setting and character of the proposed development, and to ensure that the proposed parking spaces, footways and carriageways are designed to be safe and to meet the specifications required by the Local Highways Authority in respect of long-term maintenance, in accordance with policies: 7.19 and 7.21 of the London Plan 2015; 1.1(i) of Ealing's Development (or Core) Strategy 2012; and policy LV5.10 of Ealing's Development Management DPD (2013) and interim SPG 9: Trees and Development Guidelines. | Within six-months of the commencement of the superstructure works on each Phase of the development, the details of the location of car parking spaces equipped with passive and active electric vehicle charging points within the relevant Phase shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The details should demonstrate that 20% of the parking spaces within the application site would have active charging points for electric vehicles, with an additional 20% of the parking spaces being provided with passive charging provision, unless otherwise agreed in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The approved details for the relevant Phase of development shall be implemented prior to the first occupation / first use of the approved development in that Phase.  Reason: In the interest of the environment and improving air quality in accordance with policies 6.13 and 7.14 of the London Plan 2015; policies 1.1(e), 1.1(j), 1.1(k) and 1.2(k) of Ealing's adopted Development (or Core) Strategy 2012; and  policy 7A of Ealing's Development Management Development Plan Document (2013). | Deliveries to and the servicing of the development shall be undertaken in accordance with the approved Delivery and Servicing Management Plan ref: 100001747_DSP Rev 02 (dated 19/12/2014), prepared by Project Centre.  Reason: To ensure that the resulting servicing arrangements are satisfactory in terms of their impact on highway safety and the free-flow of traffic in accordance with policies 6.7 and 6.13 of the London Plan 2015. | Development shall not commence on the installation of the multi-use games area until an assessment of the impact of noise from the use of the multi-use games area, including details of any mitigation measures required to attenuate noise has been submitted to the Local Planning Authority for written approval. The assessment should include consideration of the need for acoustic fencing. The approved mitigation measures shall be installed prior to the first use of the multi-use games area and retained thereafter.    Reason: To ensure that the use of the multi-use games area does not cause nuisance to the amenity of occupiers of residential properties adjoining the school, in accordance with policy 7.3 of the London Plan 2015, 1.1(j) of Ealing's Development (or Core) Strategy 2012, and 7A and LV7.3 of Ealing's Development Management DPD (2013). | The multi-use games area shall only be made available for use via controlled access from the approved school and / or the approved replacement Green Man Lane community centre and / or the approved replacement Jubilee Hall children's centre. The use of the multi-use games area shall only be permitted between the hours of 0800-2000 on weekdays and Saturdays, and 1000-1800 on Sundays and Public Holidays.   Reason: To ensure that the use of the multi-use games area does not cause nuisance to the amenity of occupiers of residential properties adjoining the school, in accordance with policy 7.3 of the London Plan 2015, 1.1(j) of Ealing's Development (or Core) Strategy 2012, and 7A and LV7.3 of Ealing's Development Management DPD (2013). | The external lighting to be installed in the multi-use games area (MUGA) shall be provided in accordance with the approved External Lighting Report ref: 47046590 (dated December 2014), prepared by URS. The external lighting shall only be operated between the permitted hours of use of the MUGA (0800-2000 on weekdays and Saturdays, and 1000-1800 on Sundays and Public Holidays). Other external lighting within the school playground shall be restricted to the 'out-of-hours mini-bus parking area' and the 'under canopy lighting', as indicated at Appendix C of the approved External Lighting Report, and no other external lighting shall be erected within the school play ground without the written permission of the Local Planning Authority.  Reason:  To provide suitable lighting for the safety of pupils and visitors using the play facilities; to ensure that the external lighting scheme does not cause nuisance to the amenity of occupiers of residential properties adjoining the school and MUGA, in accordance with policy 7.3 of the London Plan 2015, policy 1.1(j) of Ealing's Development (or Core) Strategy 2012, and policies 7A and LV7.3 of Ealing's Development Management DPD (2013). | Within three-months of the commencement of the substructure works on the replacement school, the details of the sound insulation and noise control measures shall be submitted to the Local Planning Authority for written approval. The details shall demonstrate how the insulation of the building envelope, with windows shut and other means of ventilation provided, will achieve the internal design criteria for classrooms, as specified in Ealing's interim SPG10, using the specified worst mode one hour LAeq,1hr spectrum noise level, unless otherwise agreed in writing with the Local Planning Authority. The details should also include the provision of alternative means of ventilation in each classroom in accordance with Ealing's interim SPG 10 criteria.    Sound insulation and noise control measures for the approved residential dwellings shall be installed to achieve the internal noise targets described at Section 4(B) 'Criteria for adequate protection for new buildings' of Ealing's interim SPG 10:  Bedrooms (23:00-0700 hrs) 30 dB LAeq, and 45 dB Lmax (fast) Living rooms (0700-2300 hrs) 35dB LAeq Kitchens, bathrooms, WC and utility rooms (0700-2300 hrs) 45 dB LAeq  The sound insulation and noise control measures shall be installed prior to the first use and / or first occupation of the relevant part of the development and maintained thereafter.  Reason: To protect the amenity of the school pupils and staff, and the residential occupiers of the new development, in accordance with policies 3.2, 3.18 and 7.15 of the London Plan 2015; policy 1.1(j) of Ealing's Development (or Core) Strategy 2012; policy 7A of Ealing's Development Management DPD (2013); the Mayor's Sustainable Design and Construction SPG; and interim SPG 10: Noise and Vibration. | Sound limiting insulation shall be installed between the approved community uses and the adjoining dwellings located above the community uses prior to the first occupation of the relevant part of the development, to achieve an acoustic standard not exceeding NR 25 Leq, 5mins (octaves) or NR 20 Leq, 5mins, (one-third octaves) inside a bedroom, and NR 30 Leq, 5mins (octaves) or NR 25 Leq, 5mins (one-third octaves) inside a living room when noise is generated from the community uses and retained thereafter.   Reason: To ensure a satisfactory standard of residential amenity is provided for future occupiers of the residential units located above the approved community floorspace, in accordance with policies 3.2 and 7.15 of the London Plan 2015; policy 1.1(j) of Ealing's Development (or Core) Strategy 2012; policy 7A of Ealing's Development Management DPD, and interim SPG 10: Noise and Vibration. | The rating noise level emitted from any proposed plant and machinery within the development, as assessed under BS4142: 1997, shall be lower than the existing background noise level by at least 5 dBA as measured at 3.5 m from the nearest ground floor sensitive facade and 1m from upper floor noise sensitive facades, during the relevant periods of operation.  Reason: To ensure a satisfactory standard of amenity is provided for occupiers / users of the residential, education and community buildings, in accordance with policies 3.2 and 7.15 of the London Plan 2015; policy 1.1(j) of Ealing's Development (or Core) Strategy 2012; policy 7A of Ealing's Development Management DPD (2013); interim SPG 10: Noise and Vibration; and the Mayor's Sustainable Design and Construction SPG. | Prior to the commencement of superstructure works to provide the approved school, the details of the installation, operation, and maintenance of the best practicable cooking extract system for the school kitchen, including the provision of a suitable extract fan, odour control equipment, with a vertical discharge terminus without any cap or cover, at a minimum of 1.5 metres above the highest roof eaves of the building, shall be submitted to the Local Planning Authority for written a
site_number: St Johns School, Green Man CC and Part of Tintern Court
